title: Screen recordings play faster than real time
description:
Game recordings run faster than wall-clock time, causing video timestamps to drift from actual game event timestamps. In game_20260210_234611, a game that lasted ~2h02m in real time (23:47 to 01:49) produced a recording where the win appeared at ~5390s (~1h30m) instead of the expected ~7320s. That's roughly 75% of real-time duration â€” about 25% of frames are being dropped.

The FrameCaptureService uses a Swing Timer at 30fps to capture frames, but under CPU load the timer likely fires slower than requested, producing fewer frames per real-time second. FFmpeg encodes at a fixed 30fps output rate, so the resulting video plays back faster than real time.

Possible fixes:
- Embed real timestamps in the video stream so playback matches wall-clock time
- Use variable frame rate encoding that respects actual capture intervals
- Log frame timestamps and post-process to correct playback speed
